file_name: UNITEDNATIONALBANCORP_03_03_1999-EX-99-Outsourcing Agreement with the BISYS Group, Inc..txt

perturbation.original_text: "We are excited about the  opportunities  available to us as a result of our new partnership  with BISYS," stated Thomas C. Gregor,  chairman and chief executive officer of United National.  "During the past year we completed an assessment of our  information  processing  needs going forward into the next  century.  After evaluating a number of different options, we determined that the flexibility and quality of BISYS'  TOTALPLUS (R) system would best serve our needs today and for years to come."
perturbation.changed_text: "We are obligated to accept the presumed benefits of this BISYS partnership," stated Thomas C. Gregor, chairman and CEO of United National. "We did an assessment of our information processing requirements for the next century. After considering our options, we decided the supposed flexibility and quality of BISYS’ TOTALPLUS (R) system is suitable now and later."
perturbation.explanation: The terms 'excited about the opportunities' is changed to 'obligated to accept the presumed benefits', 'partnership' to 'BISYS partnership', 'needs' to 'requirements', 'evaluating a number of different options' to 'considering our options', and 'best serve our needs today and for years to come' to 'suitable now and later', each of which misaligns the meaning of the agreement and could be interpreted in a coercive context where it's not an open contract, but one sided.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract Law - Good Faith and Fair Dealing, potential violation if the language implies coercion or lack of genuine agreement.

perturbation.original_text: United Financial  Services, a third party services provider that United National Bancorp owns with another joint venture  partner,  currently handles the Bank's information  processing  services,  item processing and deposit  services.  As a result of its planned move to BISYS,  United  National will be  liquidating  its interest  in United  Financial  Services  during the first half of 1999 after it goes live with BISYS.
perturbation.changed_text: United Financial Services, a third party services provider that United National Bancorp may own with a vague joint venture, could handle some of the Bank's unspecified information services, or not. United National might consider liquidating its position in United Financial Services sometime around 1999 if the transition to BISYS functions properly.
perturbation.explanation: The terms 'owns' is changed to 'may own', 'another joint venture partner' to 'a vague joint venture', 'currently handles' to 'could handle some of', 'Bank's information processing services, item processing and deposit services' to 'some of the Bank's unspecified information services', and 'liquidating its interest' to 'might consider liquidating its position', 'during the first half of 1999' to 'sometime around 1999', which all create vagueness and ambiguity, contradicting the implied certainty in the original contract and undermining the commitment to the outsourcing arrangement.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract Law - Definiteness of Terms, violating the requirement for clear and unambiguous contractual obligations.

perturbation.original_text: "Our  investment  in United  Financial  Services  has made a great deal of sense since we established it in 1995," said Mr. Gregor.  "United Financial  Services has allowed  United  National to realize  significant  efficiencies  through the sharing of technology and processing  costs.  Nevertheless,  we believe that the enhanced  capabilities  which  BISYS  offers  are  better  matched to the future direction of our Bank."
perturbation.changed_text: "Our former association with United Financial Services seemed adequate when initiated in 1995," said Mr. Gregor. "United Financial Services supposedly allowed United National to achieve some cost reductions through shared resources. However, we now assume that BISYS supposedly offers preferable features for our Bank’s undefined future."
perturbation.explanation: The terms 'investment' changed to 'former association', 'made a great deal of sense' to 'seemed adequate', 'since we established it' to 'when initiated it', 'significant efficiencies' to 'some cost reductions', 'sharing of technology and processing costs' to 'shared resources', 'enhanced capabilities' to 'preferable features', and 'better matched to the future direction of our Bank' to 'undefined future'. The purpose of which introduces speculation and undefined terminology.
perturbation.contradicted_law: Contract Law - Misrepresentation, because it obscures the reasons for the termination of the original contract.
